items.author: Desmond Ryan
items.content: The triumphant masterpiece of Akira Kurosawa's fertile twilight.

items.author: Bob Graham
items.content: In Ran, the horrors of life are transformed by art into beauty. It is finally so moving that the only appropriate response is silence.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: One of the 10 best films ever made, period.

items.author: G. Allen Johnson
items.content: Kurosawa pulled out all the stops with Ran, his obsession with loyalty and his love of expressionistic film techniques allowed to roam freely.

items.author: Frank Lovece
items.content: Stands separate from the rest, in a pantheon, a true cinematic masterwork of sight, sound, intelligence, and most importantly--passion.

items.author: Shawn Levy
items.content: In many respects, it's Kurosawa's most sumptuous film, a feast of color, motion and sound: Considering that its brethren include "Kagemusha," "The Seven Samurai" and "Dersu Uzala," the achievement is extraordinary. [01 Dec 2000, p.26]

items.author: Variety
items.content: Itâ€™s a dazzlingly successful addition to [Kurosawa's] distinguished career.

items.author: F. X. Feeney
items.content: The Japanese title means chaos, and that is what is let loose when a powerful king foolishly tries to release the reins of power, in the hopes of enjoying a peaceful old age.

items.author: Amy Taubin
items.content: A magisterial film, but not quite a great one.
Save for one startlingly staged battle sequence. . .might as well have been titled "Also Ran."
